prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our goal is to measure if there is detectable additional dust growth in the potential pressure trap region compared to other radii in transition disk of J1604-2130. The primary observational evidence is to determine whether there are differences in the sub-mm continuum spectral indices of different regions in spatially resolved images.
Spectral settings: We choose 1.3 and 3mm continuum bands to measure the spectral indices where the dust emission is certainly optically thin. We require one spectral setting at each wavelength. The primary baseband at 1.3mm is a 2 GHz wide continuum baseband at 234GHz (USB). We put 13CO/C18O 2-1 in one LSB baseband and DCO+/CO 2-1 in the two basebands left. The CO 2-1 line will trace the gas temperature in the outer disk. DCO+ is tracer of CO condensation and its detection can be combined with our H13CO+ 4-3 detection in ALMA cycle 0 data to measure the D/H ratio in the disk. In the setting for 3mm, we have two 2GHz wide continuum basebands, 108.5GHz(at USB) and 95.6GHz(at LSB). These are used to increase the SNR because the continuum emission is much weaker at 3mm than at 1.3mm. The two basebands separated by a modest frequency difference can also provide useful additional spectral index constraints. We also include 13CO/C18O 1-0 (USB) and CS 2-1 (LSB). The CO isotopologue 1-0 transitions can be combined with the 2-1 isotopologue transitions to constrain the excitation and vertical temperature structure in the disk.
Spatial resolution: The required resolution is 0."4 at both 1.3 and 3mm in order to directly compare the fluxes from resolved images. This is a spatial resolution of ~60 AU, a resolution chosen to resolve emission from the dust cavity which has a radius of 78 AU.
Sensitivity requirement: The goal is to measure the beta values with an uncertainty 0.1 or better at the ring region and 0.2 or better in the other two regions. We will measure fluxes from three regions of the disk (see Fig.2(a)), which have fluxes of 16.6, 120.6 and 87.8 mJy, respectively, at 880 micron (ALMA cycle 0 data). The cavity has the lowest flux. Its fluxes would be 4.0 and 0.18mJy at 1.3 and 3mm, respectively, assuming a steep slope case (beta =1.5). To achieve the desired uncertainty on beta, we require a noise level of 0.04mJy.

Our goal is to measure if there is detectable additional dust growth in the potential pressure trap region compared to other radii in transition disk of J1604-2130. The primary observational evidence is to determine whether there are differences in the sub-mm continuum spectral indices of different regions in spatially resolved images.
Spectral settings: We choose 1.3 and 3mm continuum bands to measure the spectral indices where the dust emission is certainly optically thin. We require one spectral setting at each wavelength. The primary baseband at 1.3mm is a 2 GHz wide continuum baseband at 234GHz (USB). We put 13CO/C18O 2-1 in one LSB baseband and DCO+/CO 2-1 in the two basebands left. The CO 2-1 line will trace the gas temperature in the outer disk. DCO+ is tracer of CO condensation and its detection can be combined with our H13CO+ 4-3 detection in ALMA cycle 0 data to measure the D/H ratio in the disk. In the setting for 3mm, we have two 2GHz wide continuum basebands, 108.5GHz(at USB) and 95.6GHz(at LSB). These are used to increase the SNR because the continuum emission is much weaker at 3mm than at 1.3mm. The two basebands separated by a modest frequency difference can also provide useful additional spectral index constraints. We also include 13CO/C18O 1-0 (USB) and CS 2-1 (LSB). The CO isotopologue 1-0 transitions can be combined with the 2-1 isotopologue transitions to constrain the excitation and vertical temperature structure in the disk.
Spatial resolution: The required resolution is 0."4 at both 1.3 and 3mm in order to directly compare the fluxes from resolved images. This is a spatial resolution of ~60 AU, a resolution chosen to resolve emission from the dust cavity which has a radius of 78 AU.
Sensitivity requirement: The goal is to measure the beta values with an uncertainty 0.1 or better at the ring region and 0.2 or better in the other two regions. We will measure fluxes from three regions of the disk (see Fig.2(a)), which have fluxes of 16.6, 120.6 and 87.8 mJy, respectively, at 880 micron (ALMA cycle 0 data). The cavity has the lowest flux. Its fluxes would be 4.0 and 0.18mJy at 1.3 and 3mm, respectively, assuming a steep slope case (beta =1.5). To achieve the desired uncertainty on beta, we require a noise level of 0.04mJy.

Our goal is to measure the dust-to-gas ratio variation around the pressure trap region and beyond by imaging the 880micron continuum and 13CO and C18O J=3-2 emission at high resolution.
Spectral setting: We have a 2GHz wide continuum baseband at 342GHz (USB) to measure the dust emission. 13CO and C18O J=3-2 are placed in two LSB basebands, separately. The 13CO 3-2 is used to measure the temperature gradient. C18O 3-2 is expected to be optically thin based on our model and used to constrain gas surface density. The CN N= 3-2 line, in the USB, is used as a probe of disk surface photochemistry.
Spatial resolution: We require two configurations. The first one, with a high spatial resolution of 0.''2 (~30AU), is needed to resolve the dust and gas mass surface density profiles near the potential pressure maximum location. The second one, with 0."4 resolution, is to robustly detect the more diffuse gas distribution of the outer disk (and to place limits on the dust at large radii).
Sensitivity requirement: The 880 micron continuum flux is 221mJy and the CO J=3-2 line flux is 22 Jy.km/s (ALMA cycle 0 data). Based on a CASA simulation of our best model fit to the cycle 0 data, we expect to detect the 880micron continuum with 2mJy/beam at the ring region. There are no previous published 13CO and C18O J=3-2 line fluxes. Using a gas surface density consistent with a pressure trap in the disk, we predict the 13CO and C18O J=3-2 fluxes are 14.8 and 6Jy.km/s, respectively. The simulated images of C18O J=3-2 show a peak flux of 67mJy/beam. The CO J=3-2 line width is 0.9km/s. The 13CO and C18O J=3-2 lines should be of similar width. The line fluxes are expected to be higher in the constant dust-to-gas ratio case because the gas surface density will be higher in the ring region. We require a SNR of ~ 20 in continuum and a SNR of ~ 15 for the C18O 3-2 momentum 0 image, i.e., 0.1mJy in a 2GHz wide continuum band and 4mJy at 1km/s width.
The second configuration (0."4) is needed to detect C18O 3-2 emission in outer disk region ( > 120AU), to ensure that the gas-to-dust ratio variations are accurately measured. The simulated images of C18O J=3-2 show a peak flux of ~60mJy/beam. We require a SNR ~10 for a good detection.

Spectral setting: We have a 2GHz wide continuum baseband at 342GHz (USB) to measure the dust emission. 13CO and C18O J=3-2 are placed in two LSB basebands, separately. The 13CO 3-2 is used to measure the temperature gradient. C18O 3-2 is expected to be optically thin based on our model and used to constrain gas surface density. The CN N= 3-2 line, in the USB, is used as a probe of disk surface photochemistry.
Spatial resolution: We require two configurations. The first one, with a high spatial resolution of 0.''2 (~30AU), is needed to resolve the dust and gas mass surface density profiles near the potential pressure maximum location. The second one, with 0."4 resolution, is to robustly detect the more diffuse gas distribution of the outer disk (and to place limits on the dust at large radii).

The simulated images of C18O J=3-2 show a peak flux of 67mJy/beam. The CO J=3-2 line width is 0.9km/s. The 13CO and C18O J=3-2 lines should be of similar width. The line fluxes are expected to be higher in the constant dust-to-gas ratio case because the gas surface density will be higher in the ring region. We require a SNR of ~ 20 in continuum and a SNR of ~ 15 for the C18O 3-2 momentum 0 image, i.e., 0.1mJy in a 2GHz wide continuum band and 4mJy at 1km/s width.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: One of the main unsolved problems in the hierarchical growth model of planetary embryos is the so-called the "meter-barrier": that excessive radial drift will drive mm-/meter-sized bodies inward to the central star before large objects can form. While recent observations support the idea that dust may be trapped in a local pressure maximum, where further growth can take place, the evidence is mostly qualitative and nearly exclusively from disks with highly asymmetric dust emission. To truly understand the mechanism(s) at play, quantitative measures of predicted pressure trap effects must be explored. Here we propose to observe J1604-2130, the only transition disk observed with high signal to nosie with ALMA which has signs of a pressure trap but shows a highly axisymmetric dust distribution, to characterize the radial variation in the dust size distribution and measure the dust-to-gas mass surface density ratio structure near the pressure maximum - a crucial observable that can distinguish between different triggering mechanisms. Only ALMA can carry out the proposed observations, which will illuminate a critical stage in the formation of planetary systems.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Geological and Planetary Sciences, California Institute of Technology
